en.title: Cycling Aerodynamics - CdA, Drafting, Position Optimization
en.description: Complete guide to cycling aerodynamics: CdA estimation, drafting benefits, position optimization, and aero equipment choices.
en.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Cycling Aerodynamics: CdA, Drafting, Position Optimization Understanding and reducing aerodynamic drag to ride faster Aerodynamic Drag: The Dominant Force in Cycling At speeds above 25 km/h (15.5 mph), aerodynamic drag becomes the primary resistive force you must overcome. On flat terrain at 40 km/h (25 mph), approximately 80-90% of your power output goes toward pushing air out of the way‚Äînot overcoming rolling resistance or gravity. This means that

en.title: Cycling Climbing Performance - VAM, W/kg, Gradient Analysis
en.description: Master climbing performance metrics: VAM (vertical ascent meters), power-to-weight ratio (W/kg), and gradient-adjusted performance.
en.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Climbing Performance: VAM, W/kg, Gradient Analysis Understanding the metrics that determine climbing speed and how to improve them What Makes a Good Climber? Climbing performance in cycling is fundamentally about power-to-weight ratio . Unlike flat riding where aerodynamics dominates, climbing is a battle against gravity. The lighter you are relative to your power output, the faster you'll ascend. But weight alone doesn't tell the full story. Two ke

en.title: Cycling Efficiency Metrics - Optimize Performance

en.content: Cycling Efficiency Metrics Optimize Performance Through Improved Efficiency Key Takeaways: Cycling Efficiency Efficiency means doing more work with less energy expenditure Multiple dimensions: Gross efficiency, aerodynamic efficiency, biomechanical efficiency, metabolic efficiency Elite cyclists achieve 22-25% gross efficiency vs. 18-20% for recreational riders Training can improve efficiency by 3-8% through strength work, technique, and metabolic adaptations Efficiency gains translate directly

en.title: Functional Threshold Power Calculator - FTP Test & Zones
en.description: Free FTP test calculator for cyclists. Measure Functional Threshold Power in 20-minute test, discover training zones, optimize power work.
en.content: Functional Threshold Power (FTP) The Foundation of Power-Based Training Key Takeaways What: FTP is the highest average power you can sustain for approximately 1 hour without fatiguing How to Test: Most common is the 20-minute test protocol: 95% of your best 20-minute average power Why It Matters: FTP enables personalized power zones , accurate TSS calculation , and objective fitness tracking Typical Values: Recreational: 2.0-3.0 W/kg | Competitive: 3.5-4.5 W/kg | Elite: 5.5-6.5 W/kg Testing Freq

en.content: Mountain Bike Analytics - Master Variable Power and Technical Terrain Specialized power analysis for explosive efforts, variable terrain, and the unique demands of cross-country and trail riding Why MTB Requires Different Analytics Mountain biking is explosive, variable, and technical - completely different from road cycling. MTB demands constant power surges over threshold, technical skill execution while fatigued, and managing anaerobic capacity across variable terrain. Generic cycling analyti

How you produce that power‚Äîyour pedaling mechanics‚Äîdetermines efficiency, fatigue resistance, and injury risk. Two riders producing 250W can have vastly different experiences based on cadence, power balance, and pedal stroke quality. Moder

en.title: Cycling Power Metrics Guide - NP, IF, VI, W'bal Explained
en.description: Complete guide to cycling power metrics: Normalized Power (NP), Intensity Factor (IF), Variability Index (VI), and W' Balance explained.

{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Cycling Power Metrics Explained: NP, IF, VI, W'bal Understanding advanced power metrics for smarter training and racing Beyond Average Power: Why Advanced Metrics Matter Average power is a blunt instrument. Two rides with identical average power can have wildly different physiological costs depending on how variable the effort was. A steady 250W for one hour feels completely different from surging between 150W and 400W to average 250W. This is where

en.content: Road Cycling Analytics - Optimize Your Performance on the Road Power-based training metrics for steady-state efforts, aerodynamic optimization, and pacing strategies that define road cycling performance What Makes Road Cycling Different Road cycling is characterized by steady power output, aerodynamic optimization, and strategic pacing . Unlike mountain biking's explosive bursts, road cycling rewards sustained efforts, efficient positioning, and managing energy across long distances. Understandi

en.title: Road Cycling vs Mountain Biking - Power Profile Differences
en.description: Understanding power profile differences between road cycling and mountain biking: VI, smoothness, burst patterns, and training implications.
en.content: Road vs MTB Cycling - Why Power Profiles Are Completely Different Most cycling analytics platforms treat all cycling the same. That's wrong. Road and MTB require fundamentally different analysis approaches. üö® The Critical Problem with Generic Cycling Analytics TrainingPeaks, Strava, WKO5, and others apply road cycling assumptions to mountain biking data. They expect smooth power, steady efforts, and low variability. When they see MTB's explosive bursts and high variability, they flag it as "poor

en.title: Cycling Power Training Zones - Complete Guide
en.description: Complete guide to power-based training zones for cycling. Learn 7-zone system, FTP zones, Coggan zones, and how to train in each zone.
en.content: Power-Based Training Zones - The 7-Zone System Master the Coggan 7-zone power training system for optimal cycling performance. Learn Zone 2 endurance, threshold training, and VO‚ÇÇmax intervals. üéØ Key Takeaways 7 training zones from Dr. Andrew Coggan based on FTP percentage Power-based zones are more precise than heart rate‚Äîimmediate feedback, unaffected by fatigue Zone 2 (Endurance) is the foundation‚Äî60-70% of training builds aerobic base Zone 4 (Threshold) improves lactate clearance and sustaina

en.title: TSS Calculator - Free Training Stress Score Calculator
en.description: Free TSS calculator for cycling. Calculate Training Stress Score from power data, duration, and FTP. Plan your training load.
en.content: Free TSS Calculator - Training Stress Score for Cycling Calculate Training Stress Score for your cycling workouts using power, duration, and FTP What is Training Stress Score (TSS)? Training Stress Score (TSS) quantifies the training load of a cycling workout by combining intensity and duration based on your power output. Developed by Dr. Andrew Coggan, TSS uses your Functional Threshold Power (FTP) as the reference point. A 1-hour workout at FTP = 100 TSS. Free TSS Calculator Calculate training
